H0.text: Fatty acids are the acids that are structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

H1.text: Fundamental acids are the structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

H2.text: Ionic acids are the structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

H3.text: Carbonic acids are the structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

A4.text: Fatty acids are a major component of the lipids (up to 70% by weight) in some species such as microalgae but in some other organisms are not found in their standalone form, but instead exist as three main classes of esters: triglycerides, phospholipids, and cholesteryl esters.

A5.text: In chemistry, particularly in biochemistry, a fatty acid is a carboxylic acid with an aliphatic chain, which is either saturated or unsaturated.
